sourceDesc.p: Information on named entities in this file has been extracted from files in the Digital Mitford Archive.

roleName.affiliation: State University of New York, Potsdam

person.note: Kyanna Hastings graduated in 2023 with a B.F.A. in Creative Writing from the State University of New York at Potsdam. She completed internships with Dr. Wilson as a Digital Mitford Research Assistant between 2021 and 2023, focusing on letter transcribing and research.

roleName.affiliation: State University of New York, Potsdam

person.note: Collin Carey graduated in 2023 with a B.A. in Literature/Writing from the State University of New York at Potsdam. He completed internships with Dr. Wilson as a Digital Mitford Research Assistant in 2022 and 2023, focusing on letter transcribing and research.

roleName.affiliation: State University of New York, Potsdam

person.note: Hayley Denis graduates in 2025 with a B.A. in Creative Writing from the State University of New York at Potsdam. She completed an internship with Dr. Wilson as a Digital Mitford Research Assistant in spring 2023, focusing on letter transcribing and research.

Hannah Kellogg graduates in 2025 with a B.S. in Biology from LeMoyne College. She worked with Dr. Wilson as a Digital Mitford Research Assistant in summer 2023, focusing on plant and animal research, and on photographing and archiving illustrations of Mitford's works.

Amber Peddicord sorted image files and encoded different editions of Mitford's letter manuscripts and the published versions of those letters. She assisted the editing team in completing and checking the encoding of Mitford’s correspondence in 1822. She graduated in 2021 with B.A.s in English Literature and in Communication at the University of Pittsburgh-Greensburg, as well as a Digital Studies Certificate.

occupation.roleName: Digital Mitford Research Assistant Penn State Erie, The Behrend College

person.note: Savannah Ricks is a coding research assistant who started in October 2022 working on Mitford’s Journal of 1819-1823 on transcription, proof-checking between the typescript and photofacsimile, as well as researching Site Index entries to contribute to the project. She is also helping with interface design for the project, designing new stylesheets and helping with the JavaScript for the Journal. She is working on a B.A. in Digital Media, Arts, and Technology at Penn State Behrend.
I'm not a stub entry; just a test case.

occupation.roleName: Digital Mitford Research Assistant Penn State Erie, The Behrend College

person.note: Tyler Cameron assisted in Fall 2022 with Mitford’s Journal of 1819-1823 on transcription, proof-checking between the typescript and photofacsimile, and contributing ideas for styling a web reading interface for the Journal. He graduated in 2023 with a B. A. in Digital Media, Arts, and Technology at Penn State Behrend.

occupation.roleName: Digital Mitford Research Assistant Penn State Erie, The Behrend College

person.note: Tyler Akam is a student filmmmaker and coding research assistant who started in October 2022 working on Mitford’s Journal of 1819-1823 on transcription, proof-checking between the typescript and photofacsimile, and researching Site Index entries to contribute to the project. He is also contributing ideas for the interface design for the project. He is working on a B.A. in Digital Media, Arts, and Technology at Penn State Behrend.

org.note: The highest order of angel according to the Christian religion.
Fictional version of the historical Venetian Senate as represented in Mitford's play Foscari.
Fictional version of the historical Council of Tenas represented in Mitford's play Foscari.

The Council of Ten, sometimes known as the Ten, was one of the main governing bodies of the Venetian Republic from 13101310 to 1797. The Council of Ten was particularly noted for the wide reach of its oligarchical influence over government affairs, the secrecy and frequent corruption involved in its operations, and its ability to punish members of the patrician class.
The upper chamber of the legislature in the Republic of Venice.

orgName.note: A family, whose members include Mr. and Mrs. Voules

org.note: Likely includes Mr. William Hayward the elder & his spouse Mrs. W. Hayward, a brewing family connected with inns in Watlington. Their son William Hayward the younger, eventually married Jane Webb.
Includes Paul Holton and his spouse Mrs. Holton. They lived in Wokingham and were friends with the Webbs and Mitfords. Source: Journal.
The family of Jacob Newbery. Surname variously spelled Newbery and Newberry, although the first is preferred.
The family of Col. Anstruther. Associated with Reading.

person.note: Whig M.P. from 1715 to 1761 and government minister. Mitford read his posthumously-published memoir, The Diary of the late George Bubb Dodington.
Whig M.P. Mitford read his edited volume, The Diary of the late George Bubb Dodington.
Mitford read his Biographical Memoir of the Public and Private Life of the Much Lamented Princess Charlotte Augusta of Wales and Saxe-Coburg.

person.persName: Charlotte Augusta, Princess of Wales and Saxe Coburg

persName.roleName: Princess of Wales and Saxe Coburg

person.note: Only child of the Prince Regent and Princess Caroline and second in line to the throne of Great Britain. She died in childbirth after giving birth to a stillborn son. She was a populat Royal and her death prompted an outpouring of grief across the British Empire and Europe. Mitford read a biography about her: Biographical Memoir of the Public and Private Life of the Much Lamented Princess Charlotte Augusta of Wales and Saxe-Coburg.
Evangelical-learning Church of England clergyman. Mitford read his Memoirs of the Rev. Henry Martyn.

Church of England clergyman, chaplain to the British East India Company, and missionary to India and Persia. Translated the Book of Common Prayer and parts of the Christian Bible into several Indo-Aryan languages. Mitford read his autobiography: Memoirs of the Rev. Henry Martyn.
Mitford read his The Prose Works of John Milton: with a Life of the Author.
Congregational minister. Mitford read his No Fiction.
Local owner of meadows in Shinfield parish. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.

Book illustrator and caricaturist. Son of illustrator Isaac Cruikshank and brother of Isaac Robert Cruikshank. Collaborated with William Hone on sociopolitical satires such as The Political House that Jack Built and The Man in the Moon.Mitford read the latter.

Merchant sea captain for the British East India Company, along with his father. In 1658, their ship was damaged and they and sixteen crew members were held captive in Ceylon. He escaped after nineteen years and wrote an account of his experiences, Account of the Captivity of Capt. Robert Knox and other Englishmen, in the island of Ceylon, a work that influenced Robinson Crusoe. He continued to work as a merchant mariner and also became the friend of natural philosopher and experimenter Robert Hooke. He spent his retirement writing about his experiences and about Ceylon.

Writer and publisher of social, political, and religious satire, investigative journalist, and reformer. In 1817, he was tried and acquitted on charges relating to three political and religious satires. Collaborator with George Cruikshank on sociopolitical satires such as The Political House that Jack Built and The Man in the Moon. Friend of Robert Southey and Charles Lamb.

Close friend, political supporter, and biographer of James Graham, Duke of Montrose. Played a key role in the defense of Newcastle-upon-Tyne during the English Civil Wars. Church of Scotland clergyman and supporter of episcopacy, he became Bishop of Edinburgh after the Restoration. Mitford read his Memoirs of the Most Renowned James Graham, Marquis of Montrose, first published in Latin in The Netherlands and later translated into English.
Mitford read his A Description of the Colony of New South Wales.
Mitford read his Memoirs of the Legal, Literary, and Political Life of the Late, the Right Honourable John Philpot Curran.
Mitford read the English translation of his Lives of Haydn and Mozart, published under the pseudonym L.A.C. Bombet.
Mitford read his four-volume collection of literary and biographical anecdotes, Associate of Frances Burney, Samuel Johnson and the Thrales.
Wealthy mine owner and writer on political, moral, and literary subjects. Mitford read his Materials for Thinking.
Attorney, legal reformer, and later an alderman and Sheriff of London. Helped establish the Royal Free Hospital. Mitford read his Account of the Extraordinary and Shocking Case of George Mathews.

Wrongly convicted of robbery and later exonerated. Author, with attorney James Harmer of an account of his case, Account of the Extraordinary and Shocking Case of George Mathews, published on his behalf. Dates unknown.
Mitford read his The Wonders of the Little World.
Brother of Anna Laetitia Aikin Barbauld and father of Lucy Aikin. Mitford read his Memoirs of the Life of Peter Daniel Huet, Bishop of Avranches.
Mitford read his translation of Dante.
Mitford read her Memoirs of the Late Mrs. Elizabeth Hamilton.
Collaborator with her sister Ann and Adelaide O'Keeffe on poetry for children. Mitford read her novel Display.

The illegitimate son of Kerenhappuch Taylor. Born about 1843 at Three Mile Cross, he was baptized at St. Giles, Reading, Berkshire on April 9, 1843. He consistently gives his birthplace as Three Mile Cross on census documents from the second half of the nineteenth century. His occupation is given as clerk in holy orders. Since he disappears from English census records after 1861, reappearing in 1891, and gives his son Arthur Harry Edmund’s birthplace as Isipingo, Natal, South Africa (then a British colony), it seems possible that he emigrated to South Africa between those dates, then returned to England. More research needed.
Pseudonymous author of The Letters of Junius, active during the 1770s. Still unidentified, although may have been Sir Philip Francis.

Whig Member of Parliament. Strong candidate to have been Junius, the pseudonymous author of The Letters of Junius. Lord North appointed him to the Supreme Council of Bengal, which brought him into conflict with Governor-General Warren Hastings. Leading proponent of Hastings's impeachment. Supporter of the French Revolution and Parliamentary reform.

Son of a wine merchant of Irish descent who made his fortune in Portugal, his family emigrated to England and he joined the British army as a young man. Translator of Portuguese literature. Spouse of Dora Wordsworth.
Author of books for children, including a True Stories series on historical and biographical subjects. Signed her works M.E.B. and A Mother.
Author of biographical sketches of contributors to The Spectator as well as a biography of Edmund Burke.
Attended Reading School at the same time as Talfourd. Newspaper and magazine editor and writer, he authored a multi-volume parody of contemporary authors, Warreniana.

Artist and antiquarian who collected and illustrated historical costume, arms, seals, and other objects of cultural interest from English history. Author of Biographical Dictionary of Engravers, Dresses and Habits of the English People, Sports and Pastimes of the People of England. Mitford read his Queenhoo Hall.

Important figure in Jena Romanticism, the first wave of German Romantic literature and philosophy. An early scholar of comparative historical linguistics. Mitford read his Lectures on the History of Literature: Ancient and Modern.

person.persName: Félix Lope de Vega y Carpio
person.note: Prolific and renowned Spanish writer of the Baroque period, active from 1580 into the 17th century. Important playwright whose works were translated and adapted for English theater from 1660.
Anglo-Irish writer and political figure, Member of Parliament and of the Privy Council of Ireland.

Hoare took several tours to continental Europe as well as to Ireland, Wales, and the Island of Elba, which formed the basis of his sketches and later book publications. With William Cunnington, he made the first recorded excavations at Stonehenge in 1798 and in 1810. He also excavated barrows on Salisbury Plain. He extensively studied the history and archaeology of Wiltshire, the county in which his estate was located, and in 1786 he purchased Glastonbury Tor in order to study and preserve it.

Daughter of John Aikin and niece of Anna Laetitia Barbauld. Prolific author of verse and prose for children, including two textbooks, as well as biographies of European historical figures for adults. Under her pseudonym, she authored several groundbreaking abridgements of British novels and stories, starting with Robinson Crusoe in Words of One Syllable. Like Mitford, she was known as a witty and intelligent letter writer.
Author of 11 novels between the 1810s and 1830s. Friend of Anna Maria and Jane Porter. After her retirement from writing, she kept a small shop in Cheshire.

Author of poetry for children and historical novels for adults. She contributed to Original Poems for Infant Minds with Jane Taylor. Daughter of John O'Keeffe, she supported him financially and assisted with his writing. Mitford read her contemporary novel Dudley.

Daughter of Rev. Henry Moncrieff-Wellwood and spouse of Sir John Stoddart. Authored works for children, set in her native Scotland, under the pseudonym Martha Blackford. Mitford read her Eskdale Herd-Boy.

Actor in Shakespearean and breeches parts, mentored by Garrick. Friend of Georgiana Cavendish, Duchess of Devonshire; Charles James Fox, Richard Sheridan, and other Foxite Whigs. First mistress of the Prince of Wales, later George IV. After her separation from her husband, she had a fifteen-year liaison with Banastre Tarleton, M.P. for Liverpool, and assisted in his political career. Part of John Bell's Della Cruscan circle of poets in the 1780s, and author of several long poems, collections of lyric poems, plays, and sentimental and satirical novels. After her death, her daughter Maria Elizabeth Robinson published her mother's Memoirs and collected works. Mitford read her novel Walsingham.

Expert on Roman sculpture and other antiquities of the ancient world. With his father, art conservator and cataloguer of the Roman antiquities owned by the Vatican in the 1780s. In the 1790s, he also published catalogs of Richard Worsley's Greek antiquities and of the sculptures in the Villa Borghese. Emigrated to Paris, where he became curator of Napoleon's collections at the Louvre and a professor of archaeology. Published 7 volumes of Greek and Roman ancient world portraits, in French. One of the experts consulted on the Elgin Marbles. He believed that Roman sculptures did not imitate but improved upon the works of the Greeks. Mitford read his A Descriptive Catalogue of the Pictures in the Royal Museum, or, the Louvre.
Mentored by Edmund Burke and friend of Scott and Wordsworth. Mitford read his Tales of the Hall.

Proponent of Whig causes such as the abolition of the slave trade. Wrote for the Edinburgh Review as well as authoring longer works on political and literary history. Mitford read his View of the State of Europe during the Middle Ages.
Mitford read his Report of the Action, Wright v. Clement: for certain libels published in Cobbett's Political Register.
Newspaper proprietor and journalist. Mitford read his Report of the Action, Wright v. Clement: for certain libels published in Cobbett's Political Register.
Legal journalist. Mitford read his Report of the Action, Wright v. Clement: for certain libels published in Cobbett's Political Register. Dates unknown.
West Indian planter and politician. Mitford read his History of the West Indies.
Mitford read his Circumstantial Narrative of the Campaign in Saxony.

Politican and friend of Edmund Burke. Early in his political career he was a friend of Charles James Fox and the Rockingham Whigs who supported the American Revolution. He later became an Anti-Jacobin Pittite, served as Secretary of War, and supported the Restoration of the Bourbon monarchy in France. He was a noted orator, and Mitford read a collection of his speeches.
Mitford read his collection of William Windham speeches.
Mitford read his Diary of an Invalid.
Mitford read his Anecdotes of the Manners and Customs of London from the Roman Invasion to the Year 1700.
Mitford read his Mission from Cape Coast Castle to Ashantee.
One of the figures whose birthdate is printed in The Literary Pocket Book, owned by Mitford.
Anglo-Irish landowner and father of Maria Edgeworth by his first wife, Anna Maria Elers. Mitford read hisMemoirs, co-written by his daughter.
Son of Mr. Liebensrood and member of a family visited by the Mitfords. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Father and head of a family visited by the Mitfords. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Mitford read his Travels in the North of Germany. Anti-capitalist and utilitarian political philosopher and friend of Francis Place, Jeremy Bentham and James Mill.

Travelled throughout the near East studying Muslim culture, languages, and archaeology; he rediscovered the ruins of Petra in Jordan and the temples of Abu Simbel in Eqypt. His notes on his travels were published posthumously. Mitford read his Travels in Nubia.
Mitford read his King Coal's Levée. Active 1815-1820; dates unknown. Source: WorldCat.
Surname also spelled MacDonough. Mitford read his Hermit in London. Active 1820-1824. Source: WorldCat.

person.persName: Prince Edward, Duke of Kent and Strathearn
person.note: 4th son of King George III, his daughter became Queen Victoria, following the 1817 death of Princess Charlotte, the royal family's only other legitimate grandchild. Served as a British army officer in Quebec and Halifax in the 1790s and played an influential role in the UK's changing relations with Upper and Lower Canada and with the United States. From 1799, he served as Commander-in-Chief of British forces in North America. Also served with the rank of Field Marshal in the French Revolutionary and Coalition (Napoleonic) Wars. He died of pneumonia and Mitford dons mourning dress for him.
Prebendary of Durham and scholar of Izaak Walton. Mitford read his Memoirs of the Life and Writings of Sir Philip Sidney.
In 1817, his niece Olivia Serres claimed that he was the author of the Letters of Junius. Serres was revealed as an imposter and forger and her claims disproved.

Niece and biographer of James Wilmot who claimed that he was the author of the Letters of Junius. Mitford read her Sir Philip Francis denied!: a letter addressed to the British nation. Serres, who also claimed royal birth, was revealed as an imposter and forger and her claims disproved.
Mitford read his Antiquitates Curiosae. Source: VIAF, WorldCat.
Mitford read his The Way to Keep Him. A Comedy in Five Acts.

Dissenting lay preacher and writer on politics and Calvinist religion, active 1795 to 1833, likely in London. First publisher of the Evangelical Magazine. Wrote a notable response to Paine's Age of Reason, The Age of Infidelity. Later became a banker in Aberstwyth, Wales. Mitford read his The Insane World. Source: WorldCat, Google Books.

person.persName: Major General Sir John Thomas Jones
person.note: First-class cricketer and British army officer in the Royal Engineers during the early 19th century, who served with the Duke of Wellington and was instrumental in constructing modernized defences across Europe during the Napoleonic Wars; he later consulted on the general defence plans for British coasts and harbours and modernized fortifications on Gibraltar. Mitford read his Account of the War in Spain and Portugal, and in the South of France, from 1808, to 1814, inclusive.

Portrait painter and writer on the theory and practice of painting and art collecting. Influenced Joshua Reynolds. Mitford read his collected Works of Mr. Jonathan Richardson. Consisting of I. The theory of painting. II. Essay on the art of criticism, so far as it relates to painting. III. The science of a connoisseur.
Tory M.P. and Anti-Jacobin writer. Associate of Walter Scott. Mitford read his Letters from the North of Italy.
Eldest son of William IV and his mistress Dorothea Jordan. Mitford read his Journal of a Route Across India.
Mitford read her The Miser Married: A Novel. Her letters were published posthumously.
Mitford read her The Quakers: A Tale. Dates unknown. Active 1817. Source: WorldCat.
Best known as a poet and reviver of the sonnet tradition in the late eighteenth century, Smith also wrote novels and educational works for children. Mitford read her The Young Philosopher. A Novel.

Sibling of writer Anna Maria Porter, with whom she collaborated; and painter Robert Ker Porter. Part of a large circle of successful male and female writers in London in the 1790s and 1800s. Mitford read her Thaddeus of Warsaw.
Writer of educational works for children and translator from the French and the German. Her paternal name may have been Horrobin. Mitford read her The Pilgrim of the Cross.

Likely the Rev. Thomas Comber, vicar of Creech St. Michael, Somerset and then rector of Oswaldkirk, Yorkshire; great grandson and biographer of the Rev. Thomas Comber (1645–1699), Dean of Durham from 1689. Active 1799 to 1828. Mitford read his History of the Parisian Massacre. Sources: McClintock and Strong Biblical Cyclopedia, WorldCat, VIAF, title page of History of the Parisian Massacre. See also Copinger, W.A., The Comber Family Notes and Queries (30 Jan. 1904): 89.
Illegitimate eldest son of Thomas Peter Legh. Member of Parliament. Mitford read his Narrative of a Journey in Egypt and the Country Beyond the Cataracts.
17th-century Whig clergyman and scholar who became Bishop of Salisbury and advisor to William III. Mitford read his Bishop Burnet's History of his Own Time.
Geographer and travel writer. Mitford read his Historical Account of Discoveries and Travels in Africa, by the late J. Leyden.

Mitford read his A Voyage up the Persian Gulf, and a Journey Overland from India to England, in 1817. According to the title page, in 1818 he was Lieutenant William Heude, of the Madras Military Establishment.
Mitford read his Remarks on Scepticism. According to the title page, in 1819 he was Vicar of Kensington, and Christian Advocate in the University of Cambridge..
Parish priest in Denmark and missionary to Greenland. Mitford read an English tranlation of his Greenland.
Mitford read a translation of his Narrative of a Voyage to Senegal in 1816, co-authored with Alexandre Corréard.

person.persName: Pierre Alexandre Edouard Fleury de Chaboulon
person.note: Mitford read his Mémoires pour servir à l'histoire de la vie privée, du retour, et du règne de Napoléon en 1815.
Civil and military engineer and geographer. Mitford read a translation of his Narrative of a Voyage to Senegal in 1816, co-authored with Jean-Baptiste-Henri Savigny.

John Nichols the elder, father of John Bowyer Nichols, also a printer-publisher. Longtime editor of the Gentleman's Magazine. Apprentice and successor to printer William Bowyer the younger. Author-editor of ground-breaking works of literary biography and local county history. Inventor of a medieval-style typeface used in 1783 to print a facsimile of the Domesday Book. Mitford read his Illustrations of the Literary History of the Eighteenth Century.

3rd son of John Russell, 6th Duke of Bedford by his first wife, Georgiana Byng. Whig Member of Parliament and reformer who later served as Prime Minister, in other Cabinet roles, and as architect of the Liberal party. Mitford friend Madelina Gordon Palmer was connected to the Russell family through her sister Georgiana Gordon's marriage to John Russell, Duke of Bedford. Mitford read his The Life of William, Lord Russell.

Historical and portrait painter. Professor of painting at the Royal Academy. He painted portraits of many political, literary, and art world figures, including Mitford friend Dr. Valpy. Mitford read his Lectures on Painting.

Career thief, forger, and swindler, convicted and transported to Australia three time. Mitford read his Memoirs. He also published a dictionary of criminal slang, the first dictionary to be published in Australia.
Mitford read his Chronological History of Voyages Into the Arctic Regions.
Published under Mrs. Bennett and sometimes catalogued as Agnes rather than Anna. Mitford read her The Beggar Girl and her Benefactors.
Mitford read her Manners: A Novel. Not related to the Brooke family who were nonliterary local friends of the Mitfords.

M.D. and Professor of Moral Philosophy at the University of Edinburgh. Mitford read his Observations on the Nature and Tendency of the Doctrine of Mr. Hume, concerning the relation of cause and effect. He defended Hume and was a critic of Erasmus Darwin.
Cook Mitford hired in Reading for Bertram House on February 13, 1819. Works for about a year, as another Cook is hired on March 14, 1820. Name unknown. Dates unknown.

Cook Mitford hired Reading for Bertram House on March 14, 1820. She is employed for about a week, then resigns or is fired, as another Cook is hired on March 21. Mrs. Hudswell tells her about their old Cook's misconduct, as reported in the Journal on March 14, 1820. Name unknown. Dates unknown.
Cook Mitford hired Readingfor Bertram House, ahead of their move to Three Mile Cross on March 21, 1820. Name unknown. Dates unknown.

Follower of the evangelical Clapham sect of the Church of England, which worked for social reform. Vicar of Harrow, who knew Byron. Editor of the Christian Observer in the 1850s. Mitford read his De Rancé: a Poem.
Satirical author and book collector. Mitford read his Calamities of Authors.
Legal writer, active in the 1830s. Mitford read his An Autumn Near the Rhine. Dates unknown. Source: WorldCat.

Minister who held several important posts in William Pitt's government, including Minister of War. Highly influential in Scottish politics in the 18th century. Played a role in the gradual abolition of the slave trade in the UK.

Captain of the City Guard of Edinburgh, attacked and killed by a lynch mob for ordering guards to fire into an unruly crowd during a public execution. Associated with the Porteous riots, and written about by Sir Walter Scott in The Heart of Midlothian.

Diarist; collector and writer on painting, sculpture, and medals; garden architect and garden and agriculture writer. He authored early works advocating environmental conservation, such as his Sylva, Fumifugium and his monumental Elysium Britannicum a comprehensive work on British gardening, unpublished in his lifetime. Mitford read his Memoirs.
Mitford read his A Visit to the Monastery of La Trappe, in 1817. Source: VIAF, WorldCat.

Mitford read his Narrative of the Expedition which Sailed from England in 1817, to Join the South American Patriots. According to the title page, he was First Lieutenant of the late Venezuela Artillery Brigade. According to a University of Kansas cataloguer, he served in the British Army during the Napoleonic Wars and later in Venezuela. The archive contains a letter written from 55 Great Queen Street, Lincoln's Inn, in London, to a Mr. Walter. Dates unknown. Source: WorldCat.
Mitford read his Mystery, or Forty Years Ago: A Novel.

Proprietor of Hookham's Circulating Library in London from 1764 into the 19th century. His sons Thomas, Jr. and Edward followed him in to the publishing business as T. Hookham, Jr.. Mitford read his A Walk Through Switzerland in September 1816.

According to title pages of his works, he was Captain of the [French] Royal Geographical Engineers, Ex-Officer of the Ordnance of Prince Eugene, Chevalier of the Legion of Honour, and of the Iron Crown. Mitford read his A Circumstantial Narrative of the Campaign in Russia. He also wrote a history of Venice. Source: VIAF, WorldCat.

person.persName: Marie-Thérèse Charlotte de France, Duchesse d'Angloulême
person.note: Eldest child of Louis XVI of France and Queen Charlotte, and the only person to survive the royal family's captivity in the Temple during the Terror. In 1795, she was allowed to leave Paris for exile in Vienna in a diplomatic exchange, and she later moved with the French royal family to Great Britain. She returned to France in the Bourbon Restoration and became, very briefly, Queen Consort of France, between her uncle Charles X's and her husband Louis XIX's abdications on 2 August 1830. In 1830, she went again into exile in Great Britain and then in Prague. Mitford read her Mémoires Particuliers de la Captivité de la Famille Royale de la Tour de Temple.
One of Mitford's greyhounds at Bertram House in 1819.

In Mitford's time, believed to be Mary Meeke of Staffordshire. Recently identified as Elizabeth Meeke, sister by marriage to Frances Burney. Mitford read her The Mysterious Wife. Wrote for Minerva Press.
Mitford read his The History of the Crusades.
Mitford read his The White Cottage. Dates unknown. Active 1811 to 1837. Source: WorldCat.

Executed for murdering his wife in 1721, he was one of the criminals mentioned in Criminal Trials Illustrative of the Tale Entitled The Heart of Mid-Lothian, which Mitford read alongside the Scott novel. The novel mentions the Muschat Cairn, a monument to his victim Margaret Hall Muschat.
Mitford read his Letters from the Continent. According to the title page, he was M.A. [and] Chaplain to his Excellency the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, and Rector of Castlecromer. Dates uncertain.
Sister of Annabella Plumptre and her collaborator. The sisters translated and wrote about German works. Mitford read their Tales of Wonder, of Humour, and of Sentiment; Original and Translated.

Younger sister of Anne Plumptre and her collaborator. The sisters translated German works. She later wrote on cookery and diet. Mitford read their Tales of Wonder, of Humour, and of Sentiment; Original and Translated.

Mitford read his A Journal of a Soldier of the 71st. According to the title page, he was A Solider of the 71st, or Glasgow Regiment, Highland Light Infantry, 1806-1815. The regiment fought in the Peninsular Wars from the Battle of Rolica to Waterloo under General Francis Dundas. Dates unknown.
Most important landscape designer of the second half of the eighteenth century. Mitford read his Observations on the Theory and Practice of Landscape Gardening.

Mitford read his A Voyage of Discovery, Made Under the Orders of the Admiralty, in his Majesty's ships Isabella and Alexander for the purpose of exploring Baffin's Bay, and Enquiring into the possibility of a North-West Passage. Royal Navy captain and later commander. Made four trips of Arctic exploration, including one to discover the fate of the Franklin expedition.
Mitford read his A Narrative of the Expedition to Algiers in the Year 1816. Dates unknown.
Mitford read her A Tour to Alet and La Grande Chartreuse.

Editor of Criminal Trials Illustrative of the Tale Entitled The Heart of Mid-Lothian, which Mitford read; and of other collections on the history of Scotland. Ballad poet who contributed to Scott's Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border.

One of the criminals mentioned in Criminal Trials Illustrative of the Tale Entitled The Heart of Mid-Lothian, which Mitford read alongside the Scott novel. He was a convicted smuggler and his hanging was one of the events that precipitated the Porteus Riots.
In July 1819, Mitford's journal mentions both a Mr. John Deverell and then a Mr. Deverell. The first may be the son of the second.
Female dog given as a gift to Mitford by Farmer Webb in February 1819 and married (i.e., mated) to Mitford's dog Mossy in May 1819.
Associated with Watlington

Benjamin Robert Haydon was a painter educated at the Royal Academy, who was famous for contemporary, historical, classical, biblical, and mythological scenes, though tormented by financial difficulties and incarceration. He painted William Wordsworth's portrait in 1842 and painted a cameo of Keats in his epic canvas Christ's Entry into Jerusalem(1814-20). MRM was introduced to him at his London studio in the spring of 1817, and Sir William Elford was a mutual friend, and Haydon’s own acquaintances included several prominent British Romantic literary figures. He completed The Raising of Lazarus in 1823. He wrote a diary and an autobiography, both of which were published only posthumously, and he committed suicide in 1846. George Paston's Little Memoirs of the Nineteenth Century (1893) contends that Mitford was asked to edit Haydon's memoir, but declined.
Comes to view Bertram House while it is for sale in 1819. May be Brigadier General Cockle. forename unknown. Dates uncertain.
Mitford's Journal of 1820 mentions both a Mr. Stewart and a Major Stewart. Relationship and forenames unknown. Dates unknown.
Mitford's Journal of 1820 mentions both a Mr. Stewart and a Major Stewart. Relationship and forenames unknown. Dates unknown.
Mitford dined at Wokingham & met Mrs. Talmage as well as Mr. Morris.

Mariner character from Bagdad who features in several heroic adventures stories in the Arabian Tales. Although shipwrecked multiple times and subjected to many hardships, Sinbad becomes wealthy as a result of his adventures.

According to Greek mythology, the Tragic Muse is often known as Melpomene, a name that can be translated as to sing. Melpomene is often repesented holding a tragic mask in one hand and a weapon (typically a dagger or club) in the other.
The mythological Roman goddess of the dawn.
The mythological Greek goddess of the soul, sometimes depicted with butterly wings.

Venetian moneylender character in The Merchant of Venice. When a character defaults on his loan in the play, Shylock demands in return a pound of the debtor's flesh, so Shylock is often represented holding a knife.
Character in Venice Preserved.
Nobleman character in Venice Preserved.
Noblewoman character in Venice Preserved.
The fictionalized Duke of Milan as referenced in Mitford's play Foscari.
A character, perhaps based on a historical person, who is referred to in Mitford's play Foscari.

A character, whose family name is perhaps based on the historical Pietro Loredano, who rivaled Foscarifor the title of Doge in 1423 and lost. In Mitford'splay Foscari, Doge Foscari mentions that he has appointed Signor Loredano to the position of Procurator upon the death of Venoni.

Acted in Birmingham, Newcastle-upon-Tyne, and Bath before appearing in London at Covent Garden in 1809. Became manager of the Coburg (later the Victoria) Theatre with Mr. Abbott, although this venture was not a financial success. His wife was also an actor at Covent Garden and at Sadler's Wells.

Military commander who, in 14231423, rivaled Foscari for the position of Doge of Venice. Though losing the appointment to Foscari, Loredan continued his distinguished military career, as did his son, Giacomo Loredan. Given the fact that Pietro Loredan died in 1438 (as well as the fact that Foscari and Loredan were bitter rivals), Mitford's fictional Loredano, whom the fictional Foscari has appointed as the new Procurator, is likely only loosely based on the historical Pietro Loredan or a member of his family (if at all).
Someone, apparently other than the copyist who transcribed the manuscript version of Foscari, made two changes to the second page of the Foscari manuscript in gray pencil.

place.note: A major street in central London that became a gathering place for writers and thinkers in the nineteenth-century and that marks the southern boundary of the West End theatre district, which made it a hub of the nineteenth-century theatre world as well.

Originally located in London's Exchange Alley district, a site of commerce in the seveneteenth and eighteenth centuries. Formally established in 1801 in Sweeting's Alley; from 1802 to 1972, it was located in Capel Court. Precursor to the present-day London Stock Exchange, now located in Paternoster Square.
Coastal city in northwest Spain near the Portuguese border.
An Italian river that flows from the Trentino region in northern Italy into the Adriatic Sea just south of Venice.
Body of water that separates Italy from the Balkans.

Known colloquially as Change Alley, this narrow street in London was the location of several well-known coffeehouses in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries where stocks and commodities were traded, thus making Exchange Alley a center of commerce that was a precursor of the London Stock Exchange.

In the ancient world, the militarily strategic location of a narrow passage to the Malian Gulf in coastal Greece. Notable for its hot sulphur springs, which gave rise to its name referncing the hot Gates of Hades in Greek mythology. The location of the Battle of Thermopylae.

The Battle of Thermopylae, fought in 480 BC, saw a heavily outnumbered Greek army defeated by the invading Persian army. Over the course of a week, the Greeks held off the Persians while exacting a devastating death toll from them until, finally, the rearguard of the Greek army that had been left to defend the strategically important pass of Thermopylae was defeated. The Battle of Thermopylae might be metaphorically invoked as shorthand for a noble though inevitable defeat, although given the heavy losses sustained by the victorious Persian army, the battle might also be invoked as an example of a Pyrrhic victory.

Southeastern European country at the southernmost tip of the Balkan peninsula. In Mitford's time, Greece was a part of the Ottoman Empire and became a modern nation state in 1830, following a war for independence fought in the 1820s. In 1826, the UK, France and the Russian empire join to assist the war effort. Mitford would also have known that Byron died in 1824 in Ottoman Greece, after leading a war campaign followed by two sieges of Missolonghi.

An Italian city founded in 697 that, until 1797, existed as a sovereign republic with an elected leader known as the doge. Napoleon's 1797 Italian campaign brought the millenia-long period of Venetian independence to an end. It did not become part of the Kingdom of Italy until 1866, after Mitford's death. Venice (and Italian settings more generally) were notably popular amongst British Romantic authors, especially Lord Byron, Percy Shelley, Mary Russell Mitford, as well as authors of Gothic novels.

Ancient Northern Italian city, elevated into a duchy in 1395. During the fifteenth century, the Duchy of Milan was frequently at war with Venice. In Mitford's lifetime, Milan and Lombardy were part of the Austrian empire until Napoleon invaded Italy in 1796, after which Milan became successively, capital of the Cisalpine republic and capital of the Kingdom of Italy, as part of the French empire. The Congress of Vienna returned Milan to the Austrian empire in 1815. Nationalist independence movements in the mid-19th century, supported by Napoleon III, resulted in the construction of a unified Kingdom of Italy in 1861.
The main public square in Venice, known as Piazza St. Marco. It is bounded on the eastern end by St. Mark’s Basilica.

Northern Italian city ruled by the Venetian Republic in the mid-fifteenth century, and again during the mid-sixteenth century after a brief period of French rule. Brescia remained a Venetian possession until the Republic of Venice fell to Napoleon's 1797 Italian campaign. From 1815, Brescia became part of the Kingdom of Lombardy-Venetia controlled by Austria and several revolutionary movements against Austrian rule occurred in the 19th century. After being conquered by Italy, Brescia becomes part of the unified Kingdom Italy in 1859.
Central European country bordered by Slovakia, Ukraine, Romania, Serbia, Croatia, Slovenia, and Austria.
The capital city of Greece. The city was named after Athena, the Greek goddess of wisdom.
Village east of Swallowfield. George Mitford and his friends go coursing there.
George and Mary Mitford are buried here in the parish church.

place.placeName: Manchester House, 29 Imperial Road, Exmouth, Devon, England
place.note: Mitford dates her opening poem in the Journal from this location in January 1819. Now called Chester House, it was once the home of Mary Ann Clarke.
Mr. Dearesley's copse near Bertram House. Mitford went primrosing there in March 1819. Source: Journal.
House belonging to Richard Body in Three Mile Cross where Mary Russell Mitford moved with her parents in 1820 after leaving Bertram House. Mitford lived there until 1851.
Fields at Burghfield Bridge. George Mitford goes there to get his daughter Field Tulips in April 1819.
Fields belonging to the Bertram House estate. One location where Mitford goes violetting in March 1819. Some of the fields are used for haying.
Plantations--planted woodlands--belonging to the Bertram House estate. One location where Mitford went firtopping and fed my robins in winter 1819 and 1820.
Fields belonging to the ichard Body. One location where Mitford goes violetting in March 1819.
Field belonging to the Mr. Dearsley, once part of the Bertram House estate, sold by George Mitford. One location where Mitford goes violetting in March 1819.
Fields belonging to Mr. Davies.
Field belonging to Mr. Pithers. One location where Mitford goes violetting in March 1819, although she did not find any that year.
Frequent destination for Mitford walks and drives, accompanied by Lucy & their dogs. Frequent site for collecting flower, including violets, pansies, cowslips, and wood sorrel.
Fields near the cottage at Three Mile Cross.
Garden at Bertram House estate.
Meadows belonging to the Bertram House estate.
Meadows owned by Mr. Bridgewater. One of the locations Mitford goes cowslipping in April 1820.
Meadows owned by Mr. Davies. One of the locations Mitford goes to gather woodsorrel and violets.
Meadows near the cottage at Three Mile Cross.
One of the houses Mitfords view but do not choose in planning their relocation from Bertram Housein 1820.
In Mitford's time, the Ashmolean collection was housed in the 1683 Old Ashmolean, a purpose-built museum on Broad Street that now houses Oxford's History of Science Museum.
Hamlet near Reading named after a bridge crossing the River Kennett. The existing bridge was constructed in 1812 and is a Grade II listed building.
Small parish that runs from Ilsley Downs to the Vale of White Horse district; historically part of Berkshire and now in Oxfordshire.

Large parish. In 1831, the Hundred of Overton contained Ashe, Bradley, Deane, Laverstoke, Overton, Tadley, and North Waltham. Overton Mill has produced banknote paper since the eighteenth century. Richard Russell lived here as vicar of Overton and rector of Ashe and Deane.
Village that Mitford mentions visiting with her father and the dogs in the Journal, 10 November 1820. They continued on that day to the village of Tadley.
Hamlet near Reading.

Small market town on the edge of the Chiltern Hills. By the late eighteenth century, it had six inns, all owned by the Hayward brewing family. Watlington Town Hall, built in 1665, is a Grade II listed building.

A fictional nation in Central America that the Scottish soldier and con artist Gregor MacGregor invented in order to scam unwitting investors. MacGregor, who engaged in an astonishing level of world-building and document forgery as he devised a parliament, military uniforms, and economic system for Poyais, tricked hundreds of people into investing in the fictional country's bonds. Appoximately 250 people emigrated to Poyais between 1822 and 1823, but when they arrived in what turned out to be Honduras (which had only just declared independence from Spainin 1821), they found themselves in a jungle. More than half of these emigrants ended up dying, and fewer than 50 ever made it back to the British isles.

item.name: flower
item.note: Flowering plants, whether domesticated or wild.

item.name: hay
item.note: Mixed grasses or other herbaceous plants largely grown and harvested as animal fodder. In Britain, farms traditionally maintained ecologically diverse hay meadows of grasses and wildflowers, mown to provide horse fodder.

item.name: grass
Poaceae
item.note: Large and economically important family of herbaceous plants. Includes cereal grasses, grasses of native grasslands and species cultivated in lawns, hay meadows, and pasture. In the UK, cereal grasses are traditionally referred to as corn.

item.name: corn
Poaceae
item.note: Edible cereal grains such as wheat, rye, oats, and barley. In the UK, the term traditionally refers to the most important cereal grain of the region; for example, wheat in England and Wales, or oats in Scotland and Ireland.

item.name: vine
Vitis vinifera
Vitis
Vitaceae
item.note: Woody vining plants important as the source of grapes. The wine grape are native to southern Europe and southwest Asia and were likely brought to the UK with the Romans. More than 40 vineyards are recorded in the Domesday book, although wine products were also imported into the UK in quantity, as the vines were only reliably hardy in the more temperate regions of Great Britain.

item.name: chrysanthemum
Chrysanthemum indicum
Chrysanthemum
Asteraceae
item.note: Semi-hardy fall-flowering perennial native to East Asia and to Northeastern Europe. Hybridized in China from the 15th century B.C. and in Japan from the 8th century; the flower has accumulated many symbolic meanings throughout Asian countries over time. Introduced into Europe and the UK and hybridized from the 17th century. Although thousands of hybrids exist, the plants may generally be categorized as garden hardy and exhibition or florist's types.

item.name: cucumber
Cucumis sativus
Cucumis
Cucurbitaceae
item.note: Annual creeping vine grown for its round or cylindrical fruits. Native to India and Himalaya, western China, and northern Thailand and now cultivated as a vegetable worldwide. Cultivated in the UK from the 14th century and seemingly reintroduced in the 16th century, when they frequently appear pickled. Cultivated in North America since the 16th century, likely imported by Europeans into the Americas and embraced by Native Americans as additions to their native vining crops like squash. During the 18th century, the cucumber, along with other summer fruits and vegetables eaten raw, gained a reputation for being unwholesome and a cause of stomach disorders. Continued to be cultivated, however, and their reputation began to recover in the 19th century. Cucumbers are mentioned in Dickens's novels, associated with comic characters of questionable sanity or morals: in Nicholas Nickleby, they are a courtship overture from an unbalanced suitor to Mrs. Nickelby and in Martin Chuzzlewit, they are a favorite of Sairey Gamp.

item.name: fern
item.note: Large group of vascular plants that reproduce via spores rather than flowers or seeds. In the UK, more than thirty types are native, including bracken.

item.name: fir
Abies alba
Abies
Pinaceae
item.note: Evergreen coniferous trees found through much of North and Central America, Europe, Asia, and North Africa. Unlike other conifers, firs bear erect cones that are raised above the branches like candles; at maturity, the cones disintegrate to release winged seeds. One of Mitford’s favorite foraging trees; she calls her collecting activity fir topping. Mitford would likely have been familiar with the European silver fir, which was brought to England in the 17th century. Other types of firs such as Douglas firs and noble firs, native to North America and used as Christmas trees, were introduced to the UK in the nineteenth century.

item.name: fungus
item.note: The UK is home to more than 15,000 varieties of fungi and lichens, including yeast, moulds, and mildews; and those that produce mushrooms.

item.name: larkspur
Delphinium consolida
Delphinium
Ranunculaceae
item.note: Usually refers to annual varieties of delphinium, formerly categorized seuparately as Consolida, which share blue, pink, or white flower spikes with their taller perennial sisters. Larkspurs flower from May to August. Some varieties are native to Europe, such as the field larkspur (Consolida regalis). They may be grown as garden plants or flowers for cutting.

item.name: lily of the valley
Convallaria
Convallaria majalis
Asparagaceae
item.note: Scented woodland flowering plant native to the cool temperate Northern Hemisphere. It was previously classified as in its own family (Convallariaceae), and before that was believed to be part of the Lily family (Liliaceae).

item.name: melon
Cucumis melo
Cucumis
Cucurbitaceae
item.note: Mitford likely refers to the European or common cantalope, although both the melon and the watermelon (ucumis citrullus) were cultivated in the UK since the 17th century. The origins of the plant are unclear, with different species native to Africa and to Asia. The plant was cultiated and traded in the Mediterranean ancient world.

item.name: passion flower
Passiflora caerulea
Passiflora
Passifloraceae
item.note: Flowering vines, most of which are native to neotropical zones in the Americas. Several tropical varieties, including winged-stem passion flower (P. alata) and the blue passion flower (P. caerulea) were brought to Europe and the Uk in the nineteenth century to be grown as garden ornamentals. Many hybrids were later developed from these varieties, although the Blue passion flower remains the most common.

item.name: peony
Paeonia officinalis
Paeonia
Paeoniaceae
item.note: Flowering herbaceous perennial shrub with large showy red, pink or white flowers. Native to the Northern Hemisphere in a band stretching from Spain and Morocco to Japan; most herbaceous species come from the Mediterranean region. Flower from late spring to early summer. Grown as garden shrubs and for cut flowers.

item.name: potato
Solanum
Solanum tuberosum
Solanaceae
item.note: Potatoes are relatively new to Europe at this time. They are native to the Andes and were introduced only in the second half of the 16th century by the Spanish.

item.name: primrose
Primula
Primula vulgaris
Primulaceae
item.note: One of Mitford’s favorite flowers, can bloom with creamy yellow flowers from late December through May in Berkshire. Native to western and southern Europe. It is not to be confused with evening primrose (Oenothera), a genus of 100+ species of herbaceous flowering plants native to the Americas. Mitford also mentions the evening primroses, which have been cultivated in Eurasia since the early seventeenth century and are now naturalized in some areas.

item.name: violet
Viola
Viola riviniana
Violaceae
item.note: One of Mitford’s favorite flowers (as it was of many of her contemporaries). Native to Eurasia, including the UK, it blooms from April to June in Berkshire. he terms viola and violet are used for small-flowered annuals or perennials, including the species. Mentioned in the 1811 Poems as well as in Our Village. Mitford likely refers to wild forms of the Viola such as the common dog-violet. Field pansies (Viola arvensis) are also native to the UK and are wild relatives of the multi-coloured, large-flowered cultivars used as bedding plants. T

item.name: wood sorrel
Oxalis
Oxalis acetosella
Oxalidaceae
item.note: Mitford likely refers to common wood sorrel, a member of the oxalis family, native to the Northern Hemisphere, including the UK. It grows in mixed woodlands and is a low-growing plant with heart-shaped trilobal leaves that bears white flowers in April and May. The plant is not related to sorrel proper (Rumex acetosa), although the two plants share an acidic taste that may have led to the similar name.

item.name: butterfly
item.note: Insect of the order Lepidoptera with two pairs of large wings that are covered with tiny scales, usually brightly colored, and typically held erect when at rest.

item.name: dragonfly
item.note: Predatory flying insect common to wetlands in temperate climates such as the UK. Part of an order (Odonata) that also includes damselflies. In the UK, there are 36 dragonfly species (Anisoptera) and 21 damselflies (Zygoptera).

item.name: grass snake
Natrix
Natrix natrix
Colubridae
item.note: Native to Eurasia, including the UK semi-aquatic non-venomous colubrid snake. Often found near water and feeds on amphibians.

bibl.title: The Metropolitan
bibl.note: A London monthly originally titled The Metropolitan: A Monthly Journal of Literature, Science, and the Fine Arts. After 1833 it was retitled The Metropolitan Magazine. The periodical was founded by Thomas Campbell and edited by Campbell, Cyrus Redding, and Frederick Marryat (after 1832). Mitford published in this monthly in 1832.

bibl.title: The Pamphleteer
bibl.note: Published between 1813 and 1828. Full title: The Pamphleteer: Respectfully Dedicated to Both Houses of Parliament. To be Continued Occasionally, an Average of Four or Five Numbers Annually. Contained shorthand reportage of major Parliamentary speeches, as well as original and reprinted pamphlets, reports, essays, and letters on current political and economic, as well as social, literary and medical issues. Contributors included Sir William Elford, Thomas Noon Talfourd and John Sinclair, among others. Special topics of particular interest to Mitford and her circle included copyright law, the laws regulating theatres, greyhounds and coursing, and brewing.

bibl.title: British Critic, A New Review
bibl.note: Conservative periodical with High Church editorial views. Published monthly between 1792 and 1825 and then quarterly until 1843. Succeeded by the English Review in 1853. Edited until 1811 by Thomas Fanshaw Middleton. Also edited by William R. Lyall (1816-17); Archibald M. Campbell (about 1823-1833); James S. Boone (1833-1837); Samuel R. Maitland (1837-38); John Henry Newman (1838-1841); and Thomas Mozley (1841-43).

bibl.title: The Eclectic Review
bibl.note: Monthly periodical published between 1805 and 1868. Focusesd on long and short reviews and topical review essays. Founded by Dissenters and operated as a non-profit; all profits were donated to the British and Foreign Bible Society. Followed a nonsectarian editorial policy with an intellectual tone modeled on 18th-century periodicals but advanced reviewing toward critical analysis and away from quotation and summary. Coverage included American as well as British literature, and other subjects and titles of general interest. Influential editors included co-founder Daniel Parken (until 1813), Josiah Conder (1813-1836), Thomas Price (1837-1855).

bibl.title: The Monthly Magazine
bibl.note: Monthly general-interest periodical. Published between 1796 and 1843. Founded by publisher Richard Philips and edited until 1811 by John Aikin.

bibl.title: European Magazine
bibl.note: Monthly periodical published from 1782 until 1826. Original title: European Magazine, and London Review covering the Literature, History, Politics, Arts, Manners, and Amusements of the Age. Early publisher of Wordsworth.

bibl.title: Edinburgh Review
bibl.note: Periodical

bibl.title: Edinburgh Magazine; or Literary Miscellany
bibl.note: Published by Sibbald, 1785 to 1816, then published by Constable until 1826.

bibl.title: Edinburgh Magazine; or Literary Miscellany
bibl.note: Previously published by Sibbald, then published by Constable, 1817 to 1826.

bibl.title: The Two Foscari: An Historical Tragedy
bibl.author: Lord Byron
bibl.note: A historical blank verse tragedy by Lord Byron that tells the story of Doge Foscari in a markedly different way from Mitford's Foscari. Mitford had submitted her play to the management of Covent Garden for possible production on the very same day at the end of 1821 that Byron's Two Foscari was published along with two additonal plays, Sardanapalus and Cain. Byron's Two Foscari was never performed during his lifetime, but it served as the source material for Verdi's opera I due Foscari.

bibl.title: The Life and Strange Surprizing Adventures of Robinson Crusoe, of York, Mariner"
bibl.note: Full title: The Life and Strange Surprizing Adventures of Robinson Crusoe, of York, Mariner: Who lived eight and twenty years all alone in an un-inhabited Island on the coast of America, near the mouth of the great river of Oroonoque; having been cast on shore by shipwreck, wherein all the men perished but himself. With an account how he was at last as strangely deliver’d by pyrates. Written by himself.

bibl.title: Three Months Passed in the Mountains East of Rome: during the year 1819
bibl.author: Maria Graham
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown
bibl.note: Illustrated with engravings. Source: Google Books and WorldCAT. Mitford mentions this book in her Journal entry of August 29, 1820 and rated it not good.

bibl.title: Two Papers: A Theatrical Critique, and an Essay [ . . . ] attributed to the Editor of the Ex-m-n-r
bibl.note: Satire aimed at Leigh Hunt. Full title: Two Papers: A Theatrical Critique, and an Essay (being No. 999 of the Pretender on Sonnet-writing and Sonnet-writers in general, including A Sonnet on Myself, attributed to the Editor of the Examiner, and preceded by Proofs of their Authenticity, founded upon the authority of internal evidence.

bibl.title: Florence Macarthy: An Irish Tale
bibl.note: Mitford records that she was very much amused by it. Later, she writes that she liked it better than the first, perhaps comparing the last volume to the first. Source: Journal entry Saturday 23 January 1819.

bibl.title: Remarks on Antiquities, Arts, and Letters, During an Excursion in Italy, in the Years 1802 and 1803.
bibl.author: Joseph Forsyth
bibl.note: Mitford records she was charmed with it in her journal entry of Monday 15 February 1819.

bibl.title: Marriage: A Novel
bibl.author: Susan Ferrier
bibl.note: Mitford records that she liked it very much; she also says that it made me laugh. In journal entry Saturday 13 March 1819..

bibl.title: Women: Or Pour et Contre. A Tale
bibl.note: Mitford records that she don't like it much--too dismal.In Journal Saturday 27 March 1819..

bibl.title: The Monks and the Giants: Prospectus and Specimen of an Intended National Work; Intended to Comprise the Most Interesting Particulars Relating to King Arthur and his Round Table, by William and Robert Whistlecraft of Stow-Market, in Suffolk, Harness and Collar Makers
bibl.author: John Hookham Frere
bibl.note: An ottava rima burlesque written by John Hookham Frere under the nom de plume William and Robert Whistlecraft. Sources: LBT, ODNB
Mitford rated it very good.In journal entry Thursday 15 April 1819..

bibl.author: Miss Tully
bibl.title: A Narrative of a Ten Years’ Residence at Tripoli in Africa from the Original Correspondence in the Possession of the Family of the Late Richard Tully, Esq., Comprising Authentic Memoirs and Anecdotes of the Reigning Bashaw, His Family, and Other Persons of Distinction; also an Account of the Domestic Manners of the Moors, Arabs, and Turks
bibl.note: Mitford may have read the third edition, published in 1819.
Mitford rated it very entertaining indeed. In journal entry Wednesday 12 May 1819.

bibl.title: Wheel of Fortune
bibl.note: Play first performed in 1795 and printed 1805.
Mitford rated it middling. In journal entrySunday 16 May 1819..

bibl.title: Don Juan
bibl.note: Published in parts between 1820 and 1824.
Mitford rated it good but wicked. In journal entry Saturday 31 July 1819.

bibl.title: Peter’s Letters to his Kinsfolk

author.note: A fictious first edition was advertised in Blackwood’s, and the first printed edition was labeled second edition on the title page, although it was actually the first edition. Published anonymously.

bibl.note: Mitford rated it very good. In journal entry Saturday 4 September 1819.

bibl.title: Some Account of the Life of Rachael Wriothesley, Lady Russell, by the editor of Madam Du Deffand’s letters. Followed by a series of letters from Lady Russell to her husband, William, Lord Russell; from 1672 to 1682; together with some miscellaneous letters to and from Lady Russell. To which are added, eleven letters from Dorothy Sidney, Countess of Sunderland, to George Saville, Marquis of Hallifax, in the year 1680
The Life of Lady Russell
bibl.author: Rachael Wriothesley, Lady Russell
Dorothy Sidney, Countess of Sunderland
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme and Brown
bibl.note: Source: HathiTrust
Mitford rated it interesting. In journal entry Tuesday 5 October 1819.

bibl.title: The Poetical Remains of the Late Dr. John Leyden, with Memoirs of his Life, by the Rev. James Morton.
The Poetical Remains of Dr. Leyden
bibl.author: John Leyden
James Morton
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme and Brown
bibl.note: Source: HathiTrust
Mitford rated it very good. In journal entry Thursday 14 October 1819.

bibl.title: Shakespeare and His Times: Including the Biography of the Poet; Criticisms on his Genius and Writings; A New Chronology of the Plays; A Disquisition on the Object of His Sonnets; And a History of the Manners, Customs, and Amusements, Superstitions, Poetry, and Elegant Literature of His Age
bibl.author: Nathan Drake
bibl.note: Mitford considered it good materials badly used. In journal entry Sunday 19th March 1820.
As Mitford reads, she rates it not very good, not so good as some of his Novels and then, presumably as she reads the final volume, pretty good too. In journal entry Friday 7th April 1820.

bibl.title: Letters from the Hon. Horace Walpole to George Montagu, Esq. from the year 1736, to the year 1770: Now First Published from the Originals in the Possession of the Editor
bibl.publisher: Rodwell and Martin, and H. Colburn
bibl.note: A second edition appears in 1819.
Mitford rated it charming. In journal entry Friday 12 November 1819.

bibl.title: Hacho; or, the Spell of St. Wilten
bibl.note: Narrative poem in imitation of Scott, written while the author was at Cambridge. Mitford rated it tolerable in journal entry Friday 11th February 1820.

bibl.title: The Man in the Moon
bibl.note: Full title: The Man in the Moon, A Speech from the Throne to the Senate of Lunataria. In the Moon.. Political satire.

bibl.title: Account of the captivity of Capt. Robert Knox and other Englishmen, in the island of Ceylon
bibl.note: Full title: Account of the Captivity of Capt. Robert Knox and other Englishmen, in the island of Ceylon; and of the Captain's miraculous escape, and return to England, in September, 1680; after detention on the island of nineteen years and a half..

bibl.title: Memoirs of the Most Renowned James Graham, Marquis of Montrose
bibl.note: Full title: Memoirs of the most renowned James Graham, Marquis of Montrose. Translated from the Latin of the Rev. Dr. George Wishart, afterwards Bishop of Edinburgh. To which are added, sundry original letters, never before published. After reading, Mitford commented that Graham was a very great man & great poet!.

bibl.title: Mordaunt: Sketches of Life, Characters, and Manners, in Various Countries
bibl.note: Full title: Mordaunt: Sketches of Life, Characters, and Manners, in Various Countries; including the Memoirs of a French Lady of Quality.. Mitford rated it an excellent old Novel.

bibl.title: The Sacrifice Of Isabel: A Poem.
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown
bibl.note: Mitford rated it an elegant Poem.

bibl.title: The Diary of the late George Bubb Dodington
bibl.note: Full title: The Diary of the Late George Bubb Dodington, Baron of Melcombe Regis, from March 8, 1749, to February 6, 1761. Mitford called it Corruption itself.

bibl.title: The Private Correspondence of Benjamin Franklin
bibl.note: Full title: The private correspondence of Benjamin Franklin [ . . .]: comprising a series of letters on miscellaneous, literary, and political subjects written between the years 1753 and 1790, illustrating the memoirs of his public and private life, and developing the secret history of his political transactions and negociations. Mitford rated itfamous.

bibl.title: Biographical Memoir of the Public and Private Life of the Much Lamented Princess Charlotte Augusta of Wales and Saxe-Coburg
bibl.note: Full title: A biographical memoir of the public and private life of the much lamented Princess Charlotte Augusta of Wales and Saxe-Coburg: illustrated with recollections, anecdotes, and traits of character, including incidental observations upon persons and events connected with the subject of the memoir, accompanied by explanatory and authentic documents in an appendix. Mitford rated it a catch penny thing.

bibl.title: Memoirs of the Rev. Henry Martyn

bibl.title: Sir Philip Francis denied!: a letter addressed to the British nation
bibl.note: James Wilmot's niece Olivia Wilmot Serres claims that her uncle wrote The Letters of Junius. Part of the controversy over the identity of the pseudonymous author.

bibl.title: The Letters of Junius
bibl.note: Collection of letters written pseudonymously between 1769 and 1772 and colleccted by newspaper editor Henry Woodfall in 1772. Political polemic critical of the government and of George III. In 1770, Woodfall was prosecuted for seditious libel and acquitted over printing a portion of the letters, which appeared in The Public Advertiser. The author was never identified and scholars' current thinking attributes the work to Sir Philip Francis. The controversy over authorship was still lively in Mitford's day and throughout the 19th century. Mitford called its contents a famous peppering and says that there is nothing so good now.

James Prior would publish a more authoritative account in 1824 that superceded those by Bisset and MacCormick (1798).

bibl.author: George Mathews
James Harmer
bibl.note: Full title: Account of the Extraordinary and Shocking Case of George Mathews: Who was Capitally Convicted at the Old Bailey in February, 1818 on a False Charge of Robbing His Master, Colonel Whaley, and Afterwards, Through the Benevolent Influence of Mr. Alderman Wood, the Hon. Mr. Bennett and Others, Pardoned by the Prince Regent, on the Clearest Proofs Being Given of His Innocence : Containing a Report of the Trial of Mathews, a Sketch of His Life, His Memorial to the Prince Regent, Colonel Whaley's Answer, Remarks Thereon, and Mr. Harmer's Letter, Explaining His Reasons for Assisting in the Development, and Obtaining a Pardon for Mathews.

listBibl.bibl:
The Wonders of the Little World Nathaniel Wanley
London
Full title: Wonders of the Little World; or, a General History of Man: displaying the various facultires, capacitities, powers and defects of the human body and mind. In many thousand most interesting relations of persons remarkable for bodily prfections or defects; Collected from the writings of the most approved historians, philosophers, and physicians, of all ages and countries. Forming a complete system of the mental and corporeal powers and defects of Human Nature. And intended to increase knowledge, to promote virtue, to discourage vice, and furnish topics for innocent and ingenious converssation. Mitford may have read the 2-volume expanded edition published in 1806, edited my William Johnston.>

bibl.title: The Fall of Jerusalem
bibl.note: Full title: The Fall of Jerusalem: A Dramatic Poem.

bibl.title: Mansfield Park
bibl.note: 3 volumes. Full title: Mansfield Park: A Novel. Published as by the Author of Pride and Prejudice.

bibl.title: Sense and Sensibility
bibl.note: 3 volumes. Published anonymously as by a Lady. Mitford rated it very good.

bibl.title: Memoirs of the Life and Writings of Sir Philip Sidney
bibl.note: Mitford rated it as stupid.

bibl.title: Popular Tales
bibl.note: In 3 volumes. Volume 1 includes: Lame Jervas, The Will, The Limerick Gloves, Out of Debt Out of Danger; Volume 2 includes: The lottery, Rosanna, Murad the Unlucky, The Manufacturers; Volume 3 included: The Contrast, The Grateful Negro, To-morrow.

bibl.title: Moral Tales for Young People
bibl.note: In 3 volumes. Includes: Forester, The Prussian Vase, The Knapsack, The Good Aunt, The Good French Governess, Mademoiselle Panache and Angelina; or, L'Amie Inconnue.

bibl.title: Comic Dramas, in Three Acts
bibl.note: Contains three plays: Love and Law; The Two Guardians; and The Rose, Thistle and Shamrock. Mitford rated them not good.

bibl.title: Letters from the Hon. Horace Walpole, to the Rev. William Cole and others
bibl.note: Full title: Letters from the Hon. Horace Walpole, to the Rev. William Cole and others, Esq. from the year 1736, to the year 1770: Now First Published from the Originals. Mitford called them delightful.

bibl.title: Mystery, or Forty Years Ago: A Novel
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown
bibl.note: 3 vols. Mitford considered it not very good.

bibl.title: Altham and His Wife: A Domestic Tale
bibl.note: 1 vol. Mitford calls it a pretty tale. Source: Journal

bibl.title: Memoirs of the Life of Peter Daniel Huet, Bishop of Avranches
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown
bibl.note: 2 vols. Full title: Memoirs of the Life of Peter Daniel Huet, Bishop of Avranches, written by himself and translated from the original Latin, with copious notes, biographical and critical. Mitford calls them very entertaining. Source: Journal.

bibl.title: Memoirs of the Life of the Great Condé

author.persName: Louis Joseph de Bourbon, prince de Condé

bibl.note: Translated into English from the French by Fanny Holcroft. Mitford called them not very good and stupid enough. Source: Journal.

bibl.title: Display
bibl.note: Full title: Display: A Tale. For Young People.

bibl.title: The Vision; or, Hell, Purgatory, and Paradise
bibl.note: Printed for the author.

bibl.title: Letters from the North of Italy
bibl.note: 2 vols. Full title: Letters from the North of Italy: Addressed to Henry Hallam, Esq.. Mitford called it very good though vulgar.

bibl.title: The Quakers: A Tale
Specimens of the British Poets
bibl.note: 7 vols. The Essay on English Poetry which prefaces this collection, forms part of the controversy over the significance of Pope's works. Mitford records she likes it very much and that it is very good.

bibl.title: Les Parvenus; ou, Les Aventures de Julien Delmours
Zapolya
bibl.note: Subtitled: A Dramatic Poem ] . . .] in humble imitation of The Winter's Tale of Shakespeare. Mitford called it very good.

bibl.title: Memoirs of the Late Mrs. Elizabeth Hamilton
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown
bibl.note: 2 vols. Full title: Memoirs of the Late Mrs. Elizabeth Hamilton, with a selection from her correspondence and other unpublished writings. Mitford rated it very bad.

bibl.title: The Rivals: A Comedy
bibl.note: First performed in 1776 at Covent Garden Theatre. Upon reading the play, Mitford rated it famous.

bibl.title: Narrative of the Expedition which Sailed from England in 1817, to Join the South American Patriots
bibl.note: Full title: Narrative of the Expedition which Sailed from England in 1817, to Join the South American Patriots: Comprising Every Particular Connected with Its Formation, History, and Fate; with Observations and Authentic Information Elucidating the Real Character of the Contest, Mode of Warfare, State of the Armies, &c..

bibl.title: The History of Jenny Spinner
bibl.note: Full title: The History of Jenny Spinner, the Hertfordshire Ghost. Written by herself. Reprinted in Pall Mall magazine.

event.label: Milan Wars
event.note: A series of conflicts, also known as the Wars in Lombardy, between the Republic of Venice and the Duchy of Milan during the fifteenth century.
